articles.headline: YouTube Is Said to Plan a Subscription Option
articles.snippet: The Web site was expected this week to announce a plan to let some video makers convert fans into paying customers.
articles.abstract: The Web site was expected this week to announce a plan to let some video makers convert fans into paying customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newspapers have digital subscriptions. Record labels have iTunes and Spotify. And YouTube is about to have special programming for paying customers.

articles.headline: Workers Claim Race Bias as Farms Rely on Immigrants
articles.snippet: Americans, mostly black, who live near large-scale farms say they are illegally discouraged from applying for work and treated badly by employers who prefer foreigners’ malleability.
articles.abstract: Americans, mostly black, who live near large-scale farms say they are illegally discouraged from applying for work and treated badly by employers who prefer foreigners’ malleability.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIDALIA, Ga. — For years, labor unions and immigrant rights activists have accused large-scale farmers, like those harvesting sweet Vidalia onions here this month, of exploiting Mexican guest workers. Working for hours on end under a punishing sun, the pickers are said to be crowded into squalid camps, driven without a break and even cheated of wages.

articles.headline: Lil Wayne Puts Mountain Dew in Crisis Mode
articles.snippet: How Mountain Dew backed away from Lil Wayne’s “offensive” reference to Emmett Till.
articles.abstract: How Mountain Dew backed away from Lil Wayne’s “offensive” reference to Emmett Till.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much street cred is too much?

articles.headline: The Doors Play Again in an Encore for the iPad
articles.snippet: The 81-year-old founder of Elektra records is behind a new iPad app that explores the music and history of the Doors.
articles.abstract: The 81-year-old founder of Elektra records is behind a new iPad app that explores the music and history of the Doors.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new iPad app chronicling the rock legends the Doors has all the bells and whistles you would expect of electronic entertainment in 2013: immersive multimedia, cloud integration with iTunes, a ready connection to Facebook. The driving force behind it, however, is no 20-something Silicon Valley consultant. It is the 81-year-old Jac Holzman, who started Elektra Records as a teenager in 1950 and remains one of the music industry’s most passionate and punctilious tech nuts.

articles.headline: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
articles.snippet: A bipartisan coalition won a 69-to-27 vote to require online retailers to collect sales taxes for state and local governments. But antitax forces hope the House will kill the measure.
articles.abstract: A bipartisan coalition won a 69-to-27 vote to require online retailers to collect sales taxes for state and local governments. But antitax forces hope the House will kill the measure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan coalition in the Senate easily passed legislation on Monday to force Internet retailers to collect sales taxes for state and local governments, sending the issue to the House, where antitax forces have vowed to kill it.

articles.headline: Foxconn Tries to Move Past the iPhone
articles.snippet: Foxconn, an electronics contractor in China that was criticized for poor conditions in factories making Apple products, is moving to develop its own goods, like televisions.
articles.abstract: Foxconn, an electronics contractor in China that was criticized for poor conditions in factories making Apple products, is moving to develop its own goods, like televisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Terry Gou did almost everything that Apple could ask for. He made all those iPhones — and he made them cheap. When Apple was subsequently criticized for low wages and poor working conditions at his factories in China, it was Mr. Gou’s company, the Foxconn Technology Group, and not Apple, that caught the most heat.

articles.headline: White House Holds Firm on Cautious Path in Syria Crisis
articles.snippet: The Obama administration insisted it would not veer from its approach, despite strikes near Damascus by Israel and new questions about the use of chemical arms in Syria’s civil war.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration insisted it would not veer from its approach, despite strikes near Damascus by Israel and new questions about the use of chemical arms in Syria’s civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House insisted Monday that it would not be thrown off its cautious approach to Syria, despite Israeli military strikes near Damascus and new questions about the use of chemical weapons in the civil war there.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Google Glass Picks Up Early Signal: Keep Out
articles.snippet: The wearable computer is prompting questions of whether it will distract drivers, upend relationships and strip people of what little privacy they still have in public.
articles.abstract: The wearable computer is prompting questions of whether it will distract drivers, upend relationships and strip people of what little privacy they still have in public.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s wearable computer, the most anticipated piece of electronic wizardry since the iPad and iPhone, will not go on sale for many months.

articles.headline: Facing Black Market, Pfizer Is Looking Online to Sell Viagra
articles.snippet: The drug maker is now selling its billion-dollar erectile dysfunction drug, among the world’s most counterfeited, directly to men with a prescription.
articles.abstract: The drug maker is now selling its billion-dollar erectile dysfunction drug, among the world’s most counterfeited, directly to men with a prescription.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer has taken the unusual step of selling its erectile dysfunction drug, Viagra, to consumers on its Web site, in an effort to establish a presence in the huge online market for the popular blue pill, considered to be one of the most counterfeited drugs in the world.

articles.headline: As Midterms Loom, Democrats Worry About Health Law
articles.snippet: Republicans are trying to turn President Obama’s health care law into an election weapon and are preparing to exploit every problem and complaint that arises as it is carried out.
articles.abstract: Republicans are trying to turn President Obama’s health care law into an election weapon and are preparing to exploit every problem and complaint that arises as it is carried out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the administration struggles to put in place the final, complex piece of President Obama’s signature health care law, an endeavor on a scale not seen since Medicare’s creation nearly a half-century ago, Democrats are worried that major snags will be exploited by Republicans in next year’s midterm elections.

articles.headline: For Buffett, the Past  Isn’t Always Prologue
articles.snippet: An investor invoked a predecessor of Warren E. Buffett when he questioned the Berkshire Hathaway chief about the company’s future.
articles.abstract: An investor invoked a predecessor of Warren E. Buffett when he questioned the Berkshire Hathaway chief about the company’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA – A little under an hour into the question-and-answer session at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting here on Saturday, a name searing with history but now largely forgotten was mentioned: Henry E. Singleton.

articles.headline: U.S. Blames China’s Military Directly for Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: The Pentagon explicitly accused China of attacking government systems and defense contractors, possibly to map “military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.”
articles.abstract: The Pentagon explicitly accused China of attacking government systems and defense contractors, possibly to map “military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday explicitly accused China’s military of mounting attacks on American government computer systems and defense contractors, saying one motive could be to map “military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.”

articles.headline: Before Escape, Fleeting Clues to Long Ordeal
articles.snippet: The authorities had been called two times to a house in Cleveland, Ohio, where three young women who disappeared about a decade ago were found.
articles.abstract: The authorities had been called two times to a house in Cleveland, Ohio, where three young women who disappeared about a decade ago were found.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — One neighbor remembered occasional late-night deliveries of groceries to the boarded-up shoe box of a house in a rough-edged West Side neighborhood here.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel, Serge F. Kovaleski and Erica Goode
